title: Frontier LLM tier list
subtitle: A personal, time-indexed ranking of frontier models.

changes.label: Initial placements
changes.note: My initial tier list based on countless hours of usage

model.name: GPT-5.2
model.summary: Exceptional instruction following and long-term agentic capabilities
model.reasoning: This is the smartest model at the moment, in terms of raw intelligence and reasoning capabilities. Others don't even come close in programming and math. It is so obvious once you actually use it for anything complex enough that it was really weird for me to see most people prefer Opus 4.5 instead.

model.name: GPT-5.2-Codex
model.summary: Worse than GPT-5.2 in general, but more efficient when working with code
model.reasoning: This is a good model, but it feels overtuned in a way that actually makes it worse than GPT-5.2 in instruction following. I saw some people having a similar experience with it. I personally don't really use it, and always prefer GPT-5.2.

model.name: Opus 4.5
model.summary: Good and fast chat model that also has some taste
model.reasoning: I don't use it for code as GPT-5.2 is far superior, but it's a nice chat model that reminds me of GPT-4o in a good way and it's smart enough for daily usage in random questions. It also works well with text and with design if you explain to it the vibe you want.

model.name: Gemini 3 Pro
model.summary: Has some raw intelligence but is unusable in practice
model.reasoning: I really tried to believe that it is a good model. But I just can't get anything useful out of it really. I still believe that it has raw intelligence in it, but Google just can't do proper post-train yet and this model is just really unusable. It doesn't follow instructions in the same way Gemini 2.5 didn't, and it is very lazy and doesn't want to think at all, even for the hardest questions. It doesn't think deeply about things unless you start handholding it. I don't recommend it for anything.

model.name: Sonnet 4.5
model.reasoning: Opus 4.5 is not much more expensive and delivers far better results, so I don't see any point in using Sonnet 4.5 unless you're seeking some cost efficiency, but in that case there are better options than Anthropic.

changes.label: New Codex and Opus
changes.note: Anthropic released Claude Opus 4.6, and OpenAI almost immediately responded with GPT-5.3-Codex

model.name: GPT-5.3-Codex
model.summary: Very fast and efficient coding model with quality close to the best
model.reasoning: I didn't really like GPT-5.2-Codex, but this new version is actually noticeably better. It still lacks the extreme instruction following and long-term coherence that GPT-5.2 has, but it's better than GPT-5.2-Codex in this regard, while also being much faster and more efficient. I'm now using it alongside GPT-5.2 in Codex, depending on the task.

model.name: Opus 4.6
model.summary: Nice and fast chat model with some taste
model.reasoning: I still don't use it for code, as GPT-5.2 and GPT-5.3-Codex are far superior. But I'm still using Opus for daily chatting, prompt writing and design discussions. It doesn't *feel* much different from the previous version, but the quality seems to be noticeably better.

Opus 4.6 is not much more expensive and delivers far better results. Waiting for Sonnet 5, but even then I don't think I'll be using it instead of Opus, as I value the size of the model for this case.

changes.label: Sparks of joy
changes.note: OpenAI released their first Cerebras-served model: GPT-5.3-Codex-Spark

model.name: GPT-5.3-Codex-Spark
model.reasoning: This model is just pure speed. And after seeing it, I thought that it would work great for very long iterative plans. But this model is just too lazy and always tries to cut corners, simply like other Codex models, but even worse. However, I found it very cool for highly parallelizable narrow tasks with well-defined instructions. Some things that would take a few hours now can be done in 15 minutes.

model.name: Sonnet 4.6
model.summary: Cheaper alternative with quality similar to Opus
model.reasoning: I still don't see much sense in using Sonnet over Opus apart from cost optimization. But this one turned out to be slightly better. For front-end and design it gave me results on par with Opus 4.6. Might be worth it sometimes.
